item.description:
In this breathtaking ceremony of remembrance, visitors to this lush, Victorian landscape make paper lanterns and set them afloat on the peaceful waters of a small lake. This ritual is based on the traditional Japanese Bon Festival, a time when a door opens to the world of the ancestors, allowing us to send messages to the other side. People enjoy picnics on the grass and a multi-cultural program of music and dance. They decorate their lanterns with calligraphy and notes to those who have died. At sunset, a candle is lit in each lantern, and the glimmering lanterns are set afloat. Drifting and flickering with the wind, the lanterns symbolize the soulâ€™s journey when life ends.

Admission is free, with a $10 donation per lantern. Parking is $10; we're encouraging people to take the T. No lighting after dark; bring a flashlight to assist your departure.

http://www.foresthill...

This is a beautiful event with lots of photo opportunities - exotic dance performers, musicians, lantern painting, lanterns floating on the water during sunset, maybe even a spirit or two floating over the lake .....

The plan is to meet at the main gate between 5:30pm and 5:45pm, then walk over to the stage and pond area. We'll try to pitch a spot by the pond to the left front of the stage. Since it will be crowded, for those arriving later, look for the yellow balloon.

Update on transportation: Street parking is limited and tends to fill up quickly. However, there is quite a bit of parking available in the cemetery for $10. The closest T Station is Forest Hills. Directions are available on the above link.
